dt: {bc}to move in or pass through the air with wings
{bc}to move through the air or before the wind or through outer space
{bc}to float, wave, or soar in the air

dt.t: was forced to {wi}fly{/wi} for his life when his enemies came into power

dt: {bc}to be moved with sudden extreme emotion

dt.t: After he became established in the town, his inheritance {it}flew{/it}.

dt: {bc}to operate or travel in an airplane or spacecraft

dt.t: They {it}flew{/it} to Florida for their vacation.
knew … a pure human-rights approach would not {wi}fly{/wi}

dt: {bc}to cause to fly, float, or hang in the air
{bc}to operate (something, such as a balloon, aircraft, rocket, or spacecraft) in flight
{bc}to journey over or through by flying

dt.t: Supplies were {it}flown{/it} to the disaster area.
He {it}flew at{/it} me in a rage.

dt: {bc}to fly an airplane solely by instruments

dt.t: She was {it}flying high{/it} after winning the contest.

dt: {bc}to stand or act forthrightly or brazenly in defiance or contradiction of

dt.t: His explanation {it}flies in the face of{/it} the evidence.

et: Middle English {it}flien{/it}, from Old English {it}flēogan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}fliogan{/it} to fly and probably to Old English {it}flōwan{/it} to flow
shortdef: to move in or pass through the air with wings
to move through the air or before the wind or through outer space
to float, wave, or soar in the air

dt: {bc}a device consisting of two or more radial vanes capable of rotating on a spindle to act as a fan or to govern the speed of clockwork or very light machinery
{bc}the space over a theater stage where scenery and equipment can be hung
{bc}something attached by one edge: such as
{bc}a garment closing concealed by a fold of cloth extending over the fastener
{bc}the length of an extended flag from its staff or support
{bc}the outer or loose end of a flag
{bc}a baseball hit high into the air
{bc}a sheet of material (such as canvas) that is attachable to a tent for use as a double top or as a rooflike extension
{bc}a football pass pattern in which the receiver runs straight downfield
{bc}while still in the air {bc}without the ball bouncing

dt.t: the home run carried 450 feet {it}on the fly{/it}

dt: {bc}in a hurry and often without preparation {bc}{sx|hastily||}, {sx|spontaneously||}

dt.t: software that handles formatting {it}on the fly{/it}

shortdef: the action or process of flying : flight
a device consisting of two or more radial vanes capable of rotating on a spindle to act as a fan or to govern the speed of clockwork or very light machinery

dt: {bc}any of a large order (Diptera) of winged or rarely wingless insects (such as the housefly, mosquito, or gnat) that have the anterior wings functional, the posterior wings reduced to halteres, and segmented often headless, eyeless, and legless larvae {dx}compare {dxt|maggot||}{/dx}
{bc}a fishhook dressed (as with feathers or tinsel) to suggest an insect

et: Middle English {it}flie{/it}, from Old English {it}flēoge{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}flioga{/it} fly, Old English {it}flēogan{/it} to fly
shortdef: a winged insect —usually used in combination

any of a large order (Diptera) of winged or rarely wingless insects (such as the housefly, mosquito, or gnat) that have the anterior wings functional, the posterior wings reduced to halteres, and segmented often headless, eyeless, and legless larvae
